'''Kazuhiro "Kazu" Kibuishi''' (born April 8, 1978) is a Japanese–American [[graphic novel]] author and illustrator. He is best known for being the creator and editor of the comic anthology ''[[Flight (comic)|Flight]]'' and for creating the webcomic ''[[Copper (comic)|Copper]]''. He is also the author and illustrator of the ongoing ''[[Amulet (graphic novel series)|Amulet]]'' series.
== Early life and education == Kibuishi was born April 8, 1978 in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://boltcity.com/2010/04/06/the-cloud-searchers/ |title=The Cloud Searchers |date=December 21, 2009 |website=boltcity.com |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref><ref name='scholastic'>{{cite web |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/scholastic-to-publish-amulet-by-breakout-graphic-novelist-kazu-kibuishi-54733912.html |title=Scholastic to Publish Amulet By Breakout Graphic Novelist Kazu Kibuishi |date=August 9, 2005 |website=www.prnewswire.com |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref><ref name='icv2'>{{cite web |url=http://icv2.com/articles/comics/view/7351/scholastic-gets-kazu-kibuishis-amulet |title=SCHOLASTIC GETS KAZU KIBUISHI'S 'AMULET' |date=August 9, 2005 |website=[[ICv2]] |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref> He moved to the United States with his mother and brother in 1982.<ref name='scholastic'/><ref name='icv2'/>
Kibuishi enrolled at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]] in 1996 in pursuit of a film studies degree.<ref name='sbnexus'>{{cite news |last=Heidari |first=Nader |date=April 30, 2008 |title=Former Nexus Artist Captures Movie, Novel Deals |url=http://dailynexus.com/2008-04-30/former-nexus-artist-captures-movie-novel-deals/ |newspaper=[[Daily Nexus]] |location=[[Santa Barbara, California]] |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref> While attending UC Santa Barbara, he credits the university's newspaper, the ''[[Daily Nexus]]'', as where his illustration career started.<ref name='sbnexus'/> Despite previously drawing for his high school's newspaper, "[His career] all began when I started writing comics for the Nexus. I actually went to UCSB for film. I was trying to quit drawing."<ref name='sbnexus'/> He would ultimately serve as the Art Director for the ''Daily Nexus'' for three and a half years, and developed his comic ''Clive and Cabbage'' during his tenure.<ref name='sbnexus'/> He graduated from UC Santa Barbara in 2000 with a B.A. in film studies.<ref name='uw'>{{cite web |url=http://www2.bookstore.washington.edu/_events/events_cal.taf?evmonth=09&evyear=2014&eventid=2014080411303800 |title=Kazu Kibuishi and Raina Telgemeier |date=September 25, 2014 |website=www2.bookstore.washington.edu |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref>
== Career == Kibuishi started drawing at age five.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://akasl.org/puffin-newsletter/2015/04/09/kazu-kibuishi-making-comics-and-graphic-novels/ |title=Kazu Kibuishi – Making Comics and Graphic Novels |last=Smallwood |first=Carol |date=April 9, 2015 |website=akasl.org |publisher=Alaska Association of School Librarians |accessdate=July 6, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304125425/http://akasl.org/puffin-newsletter/2015/04/09/kazu-kibuishi-making-comics-and-graphic-novels/ |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |df= }}</ref> He has stated that "...the sadness that came from no longer having cool robot TV shows like [[Ultraman]] around once we came to the States that triggered a lot of my early drawings and projects."<ref name='jc'>{{cite web |url=http://japancinema.net/2010/12/30/creative-spotlight-episode-9-kazu-kibuishi/ |title=CREATIVE SPOTLIGHT: EPISODE #9 – KAZU KIBUISHI |date=December 30, 2010 |website=japancinema.net |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref> He has also noted [[Garfield]] and the magazines [[Mad (magazine)|''Mad'' Magazine]], and [[CARtoons Magazine|''CARtoons'']] as catalysts for his love of comic books in particular.<ref name='jc'/>
After he graduated from UC Santa Barbara, Kibuishi worked as an animator for Shadedbox Animations for two years.<ref name='sbnexus'/> He decided to leave animation to focus on comics, where he could spend more time writing.<ref>{{cite news |last=Hunter |first=Travis |date=April 30, 2004 |title=Animator to Return for Career Panel |url=http://dailynexus.com/2004-04-30/animator-to-return-for-career-panel/ |newspaper=[[Daily Nexus]] |location=[[Santa Barbara, California]] |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref> He started producing the monthly comic ''[[Copper (comic)|Copper]]'' at his website which ran for seven years, ending in 2009.<ref name='tri'>{{cite news |last=Beaver |first=Ty |date=March 12, 2015 |title=Graphic novelist Kazu Kibuishi to work with young Tri-City writers |url=http://www.tri-cityherald.com/2015/03/12/3456346_graphic-novelist-kazu-kibuishi.html |newspaper=[[Tri-City Herald]] |location=[[Kennewick, Washington]] |accessdate=July 6, 2015}} {{Dead link|date=April 2016}}</ref>
=== ''Flight'' === ''[[Flight (comics)|Flight]]'' was conceived by Kibuishi as an anthology with contributions coming from friends.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=3128 |title=TAKING 'FLIGHT': KAZU KIBUISHI TALKS NEW INDY ANTHOLOGY |last=Weiland |first=Jonah |date=February 6, 2004 |website=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref> The project was promoted at the [[Alternative Press Expo]], where it attracted the attention of [[Erik Larsen]], then-new publisher of [[Image Comics]].<ref name='kazufriends'>{{cite web |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=3391 |title=KAZU KIBUISHI AND FRIENDS TAKES "FLIGHT" AT IMAGE |last=Weiland |first=Jonah |date=April 15, 2004 |website=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref> This caused the project to explode, attracting talent from all over the industry.<ref name='kazufriends'/> Image published the first volume in 2004 and the anthology series concluded with the eighth volume in 2011.<ref name='finalflight'>{{cite web |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=33109 |title=KAZU KIBUISIHI TAKES A FINAL "FLIGHT" |last=Dueben |first=Alex |date=July 7, 2011 |website=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref>
=== ''Explorer'' === Following the conclusion of ''Flight'', the ''Explorer'' series was Kibuishi's anthology for children using many of the same contributors to ''Flight''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://robot6.comicbookresources.com/2013/06/did-we-know-theres-a-new-explorer-anthology-coming/ |title=Did we know there’s a new ‘Explorer’ anthology coming? |last=May |first=Michael |date=June 20, 2013 |website=robot6.comicbookresources.com |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/comics/article/52653-kazu-kibuishi-s-latest-anthology-explorer-the-mystery-boxes.html |title=Kazu Kibuishi’s Latest Anthology, ‘Explorer: The Mystery Boxes’ |last=Alverson |first=Brigid |date=June 21, 2012 |website=www.publishersweekly.com |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref> Seen as a successor series, ''Explorer'' covered three books and concluded with ''Explorer: The Hidden Doors''.<ref name='tri'/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=55314 |title=KAZU KIBUISHI CONTINUES THE SAGA OF "AMULET" |last=Dueben |first=Alex |date=September 5, 2014 |website=robot6.comicbookresources.com |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://boltcity.com/2014/10/08/explorer-the-hidden-doors/ |title=Explorer: The Hidden Doors |date=October 8, 2014 |website=boltcity.com |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref>
=== ''Amulet'' === Kibuishi is the creator of ''[[Amulet (graphic novel series)|Amulet]]'', a series of graphic novels which debuted in 2008 with ''[[Amulet: The Stonekeeper|The Stonekeeper]]''.<ref name='scholastic'/><ref name='icv2'/> [[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic]] won the rights to publish the series after they were victorious in a hotly contested auction.<ref name='scholastic'/><ref name='icv2'/> In addition to ''The Stonekeeper'', other titles in the series include ''The Stonekeeper's Curse'', ''The Cloud Searchers'', ''The Last Council'', ''Prince of the Elves'', ''Escape From Lucien'' and ''Firelight''. The series is scheduled to run through nine books.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://boltcity.com/2015/02/23/new-books-on-the-way/ |title=New Books On The Way! |date=February 23, 2015 |website=boltcity.com |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref>
=== Other projects === While editing ''Flight'' Volume 1, Kibuishi created the 4-issue [[steampunk]] graphic novel ''Daisy Kutter: The Last Train'', published by [[Viper Comics]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=3618 |title=KAZU GET YOUR GUN: KAZU KIBUISHI TALKS "DAISY KUTTER" |last=Weiland |first=Jonah |date=June 9, 2004 |website=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref>
Through his relationship with Scholastic, Kibuishi was asked to illustrate the covers for the ''[[Harry Potter]]'' novels for inclusion in the 15th anniversary edition box set.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/2013/02/new-harry-potter-covers/ |title=New Harry Potter Covers by Kazu Kibuishi |last=Liu |first=Jonathan H. |date=February 13, 2013 |website=[[Wired (website)|Wired]] |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref><ref name='reading'>{{cite web |url=http://www.literacyworldwide.org/blog/literacy-daily/2014/08/15/5-questions-with-kazu-kibuishi-(amulet-series) |title=5 Questions With… Kazu Kibuishi (Amulet series) |last=Hall |first=April |date=August 15, 2014 |website=www.reading.org |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref>
He also illustrated the story "?" for the short story collection ''[[Machine of Death]]''.
== Honors and awards == Kibuishi's ''[[Flight (comics)|Flight]]'' Volume 2 was nominated for the 2006 [[Eisner Award]] for Best Anthology.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hahnlibrary.net/comics/awards/eisner06.php |title=2006 Will Eisner Comic Industry Awards |website=www.hahnlibrary.net |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref> ''Daisy Kutter: The Last Train'' was named as one of the 2006 Best Books for Young Adults by the [[Young Adult Library Services Association]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ala.org/yalsa/booklistsawards/booklists/bestbooksya/annotations/06bbya |title=2006 Best Books for Young Adults with annotations |website=www.ala.org |accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref>
His series ''[[Amulet (graphic novel series)|Amulet]]'' has spent numerous weeks on ''[[The New York Times]]''' [[The New York Times Best Seller list|Best Seller list]].<ref name='uw'/>
== Personal life == Kibuishi is married to fellow illustrator and collaborator [[Amy Kim Ganter]].<ref name='uw'/> He has two children, Juni and Sophie.<ref name='uw'/> He resides in [[Bellevue, Washington]].<ref name='tri'/> He suffered a life-threatening case of bacterial [[meningitis]] which resulted in a hospital stay for weeks and being induced into a coma for treatment.<ref name='reading'/>
